canonical_explanation.text: In physics, work is done when a force acts on an object and causes displacement in the direction of the force. Work = Force × Displacement × cos θ. Work is measured in Joules (J). No work is done when the force is perpendicular to displacement (like carrying a bag horizontally) or when there is no displacement. Kinetic energy (KE = ½mv²) is the energy of a body in motion, and potential energy (PE = mgh) is energy due to position or height. The work-energy theorem states that work done equals change in kinetic energy. The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed. Power is the rate of doing work (P = W/t) measured in Watts. The commercial unit of energy is kilowatt-hour (kWh), where 1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J.
rules: Work = Force × Displacement × cos θ; SI unit is Joule (J).
Work is zero when displacement is zero or force is perpendicular to displacement.
Positive work: force and displacement in same direction.
Negative work: force and displacement in opposite directions.
Work-energy theorem: Work done = Change in KE.
Law of conservation of energy: energy is neither created nor destroyed.
Power = Work / Time; SI unit is Watt (W).

questions.question_text: Work is done when:

options.text: A force acts on a body but the body does not move
A force causes displacement in the direction of the force
A body moves without any force acting on it
A person holds a heavy bag without moving

questions.explanation_correct: Work is done when a force acts on a body and causes displacement in the direction of the force. Both force and displacement must be present, and there must be a component of force along the direction of displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No work is done if there is no displacement (A, D) or no force (C). Work requires both a force and displacement with a component of force in the direction of displacement.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of work is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is the Joule (J). 1 Joule = 1 Newton × 1 metre. Work is the product of force and displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton is the unit of force, Watt is the unit of power, and Pascal is the unit of pressure. The SI unit of work is the Joule (J).

questions.question_text: The work done by a force of 10 N in moving an object through 5 m in the direction of the force is:
questions.explanation_correct: Work = Force × Displacement = 10 × 5 = 50 J. Since force and displacement are in the same direction, the work is positive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: W = F × d = 10 × 5 = 50 J. 2 J divides instead of multiplying, and 15 J adds instead. The correct answer is 50 J.

questions.question_text: A porter carries a suitcase on his head and walks on a level road. The work done by the force of gravity on the suitcase is:
questions.explanation_correct: The force of gravity acts vertically downward, but the displacement is horizontal. Since the force is perpendicular to the displacement (θ = 90°), the work done is W = F × d × cos 90° = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When force is perpendicular to displacement, cos 90° = 0, making work = 0. On a level road, gravity (downward) is perpendicular to horizontal displacement, so no work is done by gravity.

questions.question_text: When is the work done by a force negative?

options.text: When force and displacement are in the same direction
When force and displacement are perpendicular
When force and displacement are in opposite directions

questions.explanation_correct: Work is negative when the force and displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°). For example, friction does negative work because it opposes the direction of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same direction gives positive work. Perpendicular gives zero work. No displacement gives zero work. Opposite directions (θ = 180°, cos 180° = −1) give negative work.

questions.question_text: A force of 5 N moves a body through 3 m in the direction of the force and then 2 m in the opposite direction. What is the total work done?
questions.explanation_correct: Work in direction of force = 5 × 3 = 15 J (positive). Work opposite to force = 5 × 2 × cos 180° = −10 J (negative). Total work = 15 + (−10) = 5 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total work = W₁ + W₂ = 5(3) + 5(2)(−1) = 15 − 10 = 5 J. You cannot simply use total displacement because force direction must be considered for each part.

questions.question_text: The kinetic energy of a body of mass m moving with velocity v is:
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of a body is KE = ½mv², where m is the mass and v is the velocity. It is the energy possessed by a body due to its motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: mv is momentum, not kinetic energy. mv² is missing the ½ factor. The correct formula for kinetic energy is KE = ½mv².

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg is moving with a velocity of 4 m/s. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation_incorrect: KE = ½mv² = ½ × 2 × 16 = 16 J. 8 J forgets to square the velocity. 32 J misses the ½ factor. The correct answer is 16 J.

questions.question_text: If the velocity of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: KE = ½mv². If velocity doubles (v → 2v), KE = ½m(2v)² = ½m(4v²) = 4 × ½mv² = 4 times the original KE. Kinetic energy is proportional to the square of velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since KE ∝ v², doubling velocity quadruples the kinetic energy (2² = 4). It does not simply double.

questions.question_text: Two bodies have the same kinetic energy. If the mass of the first is 4 times the mass of the second, the ratio of their velocities (v₁:v₂) is:
questions.explanation_correct: ½m₁v₁² = ½m₂v₂². Since m₁ = 4m₂: 4m₂v₁² = m₂v₂² → v₁²/v₂² = 1/4 → v₁/v₂ = 1/2. The ratio is 1:2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting kinetic energies equal: ½(4m)v₁² = ½mv₂² → 4v₁² = v₂² → v₁/v₂ = 1/2 = 1:2. The heavier body moves slower.

questions.question_text: The potential energy of a body of mass m at height h above the ground is:
questions.explanation_correct: The gravitational potential energy of a body at height h is PE = mgh, where m is mass, g is acceleration due to gravity, and h is the height above the reference level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potential energy = mgh. There is no ½ factor (that is for kinetic energy). The formula directly multiplies mass, gravitational acceleration, and height.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 5 kg is raised to a height of 10 m. What is its potential energy? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_incorrect: PE = mgh = 5 × 10 × 10 = 500 J. 50 J omits one factor, 250 J adds a ½ factor. The correct potential energy is 500 J.

questions.question_text: If the height of an object above the ground is tripled, its gravitational potential energy:
questions.explanation_correct: PE = mgh. Since PE is directly proportional to h, tripling the height triples the potential energy: PE' = mg(3h) = 3mgh = 3PE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PE ∝ h (directly proportional). Tripling h triples PE. It does not become nine times (that would happen if PE were proportional to h²).

questions.question_text: The law of conservation of energy states that:

options.text: Energy can be created but not destroyed
Energy can be destroyed but not created
Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed
Energy remains in the same form always

questions.explanation_correct: The law of conservation of energy states that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. It can only be transformed from one form to another. The total energy of an isolated system remains constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy cannot be created or destroyed — only converted from one form to another. The total energy in an isolated system is always conserved.

questions.question_text: When a ball is dropped from a height, which energy transformation occurs?
questions.explanation_correct: When a ball is dropped, it falls due to gravity. Its height decreases (PE decreases) and its speed increases (KE increases). Potential energy is being converted to kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A falling ball loses height (losing PE) and gains speed (gaining KE). The transformation is from potential energy to kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: A freely falling body has maximum kinetic energy:
questions.explanation_correct: As a body falls, its PE converts to KE. At the highest point, PE is maximum and KE is zero. Just before hitting the ground, all PE has been converted to KE, so KE is maximum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KE increases as the body falls. Maximum KE occurs just before hitting the ground, where all potential energy has been converted to kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 1 kg is dropped from a height of 20 m. What is its velocity just before hitting the ground? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: By conservation of energy: mgh = ½mv² → v² = 2gh = 2 × 10 × 20 = 400 → v = 20 m/s. Or using v² = u² + 2gs = 0 + 400 = 400 → v = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using energy conservation: v = √(2gh) = √(400) = 20 m/s. 14.14 m/s = √200 uses wrong values. The correct velocity is 20 m/s.

questions.question_text: Power is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Power is the rate of doing work. P = Work / Time = W/t. It tells us how fast work is being done. The SI unit is the Watt (W).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force × Displacement is work, not power. Power is work done per unit time: P = W/t.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of power is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of power is the Watt (W). 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second. It represents the rate of energy transfer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Joule is the unit of work/energy, Newton is the unit of force, and kilowatt-hour is the commercial unit of energy. The SI unit of power is the Watt.

questions.question_text: A person does 600 J of work in 30 seconds. What is the power?
questions.explanation_correct: Power = Work / Time = 600 / 30 = 20 W. The person generates power at a rate of 20 watts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P = W/t = 600/30 = 20 W. 18000 W multiplies instead of dividing. The correct power is 20 W.

questions.question_text: 1 kilowatt-hour (kWh) is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. This is the commercial unit of electrical energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1 kWh = 1 kW × 1 hour = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. 3600 J would be 1 W × 1 hour. The correct value is 3.6 × 10⁶ J.

questions.question_text: A pump lifts 200 kg of water through a height of 10 m in 20 seconds. What is the power of the pump? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work done = mgh = 200 × 10 × 10 = 20000 J. Power = 20000/20 = 1000 W. Other options arise from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: A 10 kg body moving at 5 m/s is brought to rest by a force. The work done by the force is:
questions.explanation_correct: Work = Change in KE = Final KE − Initial KE = 0 − ½(10)(25) = −125 J. The work is negative because the force opposes the motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work = ΔKE = ½mv²(final) − ½mv²(initial) = 0 − 125 = −125 J. The negative sign indicates the force acts opposite to displacement (it decelerates the body).

questions.question_text: A body is moved along a closed path. The work done by the gravitational force is:
questions.explanation_correct: Gravitational force is a conservative force. The work done by a conservative force along a closed path is always zero, since the body returns to its starting position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For conservative forces like gravity, work done in a closed path (returning to the start) is zero. The body returns to the same height, so net work by gravity is zero.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 0.5 kg is thrown upward with velocity 20 m/s. At what height will its KE equal its PE? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Total energy = ½mv² = ½(0.5)(400) = 100 J. When KE = PE, each = 50 J. PE = mgh → 50 = 0.5 × 10 × h → h = 10 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total energy = 100 J. At the point where KE = PE, each is 50 J. 50 = mgh = 0.5 × 10 × h → h = 10 m.

questions.question_text: An electric heater is rated 1000 W. How much energy does it consume in 2 hours?
questions.explanation_correct: Energy = Power × Time = 1000 W × 2 h = 1 kW × 2 h = 2 kWh. In joules, this is 2 × 3.6 × 10⁶ = 7.2 × 10⁶ J. Both A and D are correct values in different units, but kWh is the standard commercial unit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy = P × t = 1 kW × 2 h = 2 kWh. This equals 7.2 × 10⁶ J, but the most direct answer is 2 kWh.

questions.question_text: A coolie lifts a bag weighing 100 N through a vertical height of 1.5 m. The work done by the coolie is:
questions.explanation_correct: Work = Force × Displacement = 100 N × 1.5 m = 150 J. The force (upward) and displacement (upward) are in the same direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: W = F × d = 100 × 1.5 = 150 J. The lifting force and vertical displacement are in the same direction, giving positive work.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg has a momentum of 10 kg·m/s. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation_correct: p = mv → v = p/m = 10/2 = 5 m/s. KE = ½mv² = ½ × 2 × 25 = 25 J. Alternatively, KE = p²/(2m) = 100/4 = 25 J.

questions.question_text: At what height will a body of mass 0.5 kg have potential energy of 100 J? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
Which energy transformation takes place in a hydroelectric power plant?
questions.explanation_correct: In a hydroelectric power plant, water stored at a height has potential energy. As it flows down, PE converts to KE. The kinetic energy of water rotates turbines, which convert it to electrical energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydroelectric power plants use the energy of falling water: PE → KE → electrical energy. Chemical energy is used in thermal plants, nuclear in nuclear plants.

questions.question_text: Work done by a force is zero when the displacement is perpendicular to the force.
questions.explanation_correct: True. When force and displacement are perpendicular (θ = 90°), W = Fd cos 90° = 0. For example, the work done by gravity on an object moving horizontally is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Since W = Fd cos θ and cos 90° = 0, the work done when force is perpendicular to displacement is always zero.

questions.question_text: A body at rest has zero kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_correct: True. KE = ½mv². When a body is at rest, v = 0, so KE = ½m(0)² = 0. A body at rest has no kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Since KE = ½mv² and v = 0 for a body at rest, the kinetic energy is zero.

questions.question_text: Two objects of masses 2 kg and 5 kg are raised to the same height. Which object has more potential energy?
questions.explanation_correct: PE = mgh. At the same height (h) and same g, PE depends on mass. The 5 kg object has more mass and therefore more potential energy: PE₅ = 5gh > PE₂ = 2gh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PE = mgh. Since height and g are the same, the heavier object (5 kg) has greater PE. PE is directly proportional to mass.

questions.question_text: Energy can be converted from one form to another.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Energy can be transformed from one form to another. For example, electrical energy to light energy in a bulb, chemical energy to kinetic energy in a car engine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Energy transformations happen all around us — potential to kinetic, chemical to electrical, etc.

questions.question_text: A machine with higher power always does more work than one with lower power.
questions.explanation_correct: False. Power is the rate of doing work (P = W/t). A machine with higher power does work faster, but it may not do more total work. The total work also depends on how long the machine operates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher power means faster work, not necessarily more work. Total work = Power × Time. A low-power machine running for a long time can do more work than a high-power one running briefly.

questions.question_text: The work done by kinetic friction on a sliding object is:
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic friction always acts opposite to the direction of motion. Since force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by kinetic friction is always negative (W = Fd cos 180° = −Fd).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kinetic friction opposes the direction of motion, so the angle between force and displacement is 180°. cos 180° = −1, making the work always negative.

questions.question_text: For a freely falling body, the sum of kinetic energy and potential energy at any point during the fall remains constant.
questions.explanation_correct: True. By the law of conservation of energy, the total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant during free fall (ignoring air resistance). As the body falls, PE converts to KE, but the sum stays the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. In free fall, total energy = KE + PE = constant. PE decreases as height decreases, while KE increases as speed increases, keeping the total unchanged.

questions.question_text: Work is equal to the product of force and ___ in the direction of force.
questions.explanation_correct: Work = Force × Displacement (in the direction of force). The displacement must have a component along the force for work to be done.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'displacement'. Work requires a displacement in the direction of the applied force.

questions.question_text: The energy possessed by a body due to its motion is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy is the energy a body possesses due to its motion. KE = ½mv². A body at rest has zero kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potential energy is due to position, chemical energy is stored in bonds, nuclear energy is in the nucleus. Energy due to motion is specifically called kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: The energy possessed by a body due to its position or height is called ___ energy.
questions.explanation_correct: Potential energy is the energy stored in a body due to its position or configuration. Gravitational PE = mgh for a body at height h above a reference level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'potential'. Gravitational potential energy depends on mass, height, and acceleration due to gravity.

questions.question_text: The commercial unit of electrical energy is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The commercial (or trade) unit of electrical energy is the kilowatt-hour (kWh). 1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. Electricity bills are calculated in kWh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'kilowatt-hour' (kWh). It equals 1000 watts of power consumed for 1 hour, or 3.6 × 10⁶ joules.

questions.question_text: 1 Watt is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second (1 W = 1 J/s). Power is the rate of doing work, so its unit equals the unit of energy (Joule) divided by the unit of time (second).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Power = Work/Time, so 1 W = 1 J/1 s = 1 J/s. Newton per second is not a standard unit. Joule per minute or hour would be much smaller power units.

questions.question_text: A boy pushes a wall with a force of 50 N but the wall does not move. The work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: Work = Force × Displacement. Since the wall does not move, displacement = 0. Therefore, W = 50 × 0 = 0 J. No work is done without displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Despite the force applied, there is no displacement of the wall. W = F × d = 50 × 0 = 0 J. Force alone does not constitute work.

questions.question_text: Two bodies of masses m and 2m have equal momentum. The ratio of their kinetic energies is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE = p²/(2m). With equal p: KE₁ = p²/(2m), KE₂ = p²/(2·2m) = p²/(4m). Ratio = KE₁/KE₂ = [p²/(2m)] / [p²/(4m)] = 4m/2m = 2. So KE₁:KE₂ = 2:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using KE = p²/2m: for equal momentum, KE is inversely proportional to mass. KE₁/KE₂ = m₂/m₁ = 2m/m = 2. The ratio is 2:1.

questions.question_text: A 2 kg ball is dropped from rest at a height of 5 m. What is its kinetic energy at height 2 m? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Total energy at top = PE = mgh = 2 × 10 × 5 = 100 J. PE at height 2 m = 2 × 10 × 2 = 40 J. By conservation: KE = Total − PE = 100 − 40 = 60 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 5 m: total energy = 100 J (all PE). At 2 m: PE = 40 J. By conservation, KE = 100 − 40 = 60 J.

questions.question_text: A boy of mass 50 kg runs up a staircase of 20 steps, each 20 cm high. What is the work done against gravity? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Total height = 20 × 0.2 m = 4 m. Work done = mgh = 50 × 10 × 4 = 2000 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Height = 20 steps × 0.2 m = 4 m. Work = mgh = 50 × 10 × 4 = 2000 J. Converting 20 cm to 0.2 m is essential.

questions.question_text: Two motors A and B lift 100 kg of water to a height of 10 m. Motor A takes 5 seconds and Motor B takes 10 seconds. Which motor has more power?
questions.explanation_correct: Both do the same work (mgh = 100 × 10 × 10 = 10000 J). Power A = 10000/5 = 2000 W. Power B = 10000/10 = 1000 W. Motor A has more power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same work but different times: P_A = 10000/5 = 2000 W, P_B = 10000/10 = 1000 W. Motor A is more powerful because it does the same work in less time.

questions.question_text: In which case is energy conserved but mechanical energy is NOT conserved?

options.text: A ball rolling on a frictionless surface
A block sliding on a rough surface

questions.explanation_correct: On a rough surface, friction converts some mechanical energy into heat. Total energy is conserved (law of conservation of energy), but mechanical energy (KE + PE) decreases because some is lost to heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In free fall, frictionless surfaces, and vacuum pendulums, mechanical energy is conserved. On a rough surface, friction converts mechanical energy to heat, so mechanical energy is not conserved (though total energy still is).

questions.question_text: The total energy of a freely falling body at any point is equal to the ___ energy at the starting point.
questions.explanation_correct: At the starting point (at rest), all energy is potential energy (KE = 0). As the body falls, PE converts to KE, but the total remains equal to the initial PE at the top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'potential'. Since the body starts from rest at the top, its total energy equals its initial potential energy, which is conserved throughout the fall.

questions.question_text: When force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When force and displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°), work = Fd cos 180° = −Fd. The work done is negative. Example: friction does negative work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'negative'. cos 180° = −1, so the work becomes negative when force opposes displacement.
